bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Willard L. Beaulac, November 28, 1952

div1.p: Hench is pleased that Beaulac, the American Ambassador to Cuba, will hold a reception following the Camp Lazear dedication. Hench forwards a copy of his remarks for the dedication so that Beaulac may be better informed about the history and persons associated with Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Willard L. Beaulac, November 28, 1952
div1.opener:
November 28, 1952
Mr. Willard L. Beaulac
American Ambassador
American Embassy
Habana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Beaulac:
div1.p:
I am delighted to know that you are in the land of the living. My previous
letter was addressed as a result of misinformation given to me by a colleague
here who is supposed to know all about such things. He is now hanging his head
in the corner.

Your letter was very gracious and it is extremely kind of you to suggest giving
a reception for certain Americans and Cubans. I certainly hope and expect that
are this you have received an official invitation and information about the af-
fair. However I know my Cuban friends well enough to know that manana can mean
a long time. They have been mentioning the participation of the American Embassy
in this planned ceremony for months but it may well be that you will receive the
invitation minutes before the ceremony!

Although Dr. Pedro Nogueira's name does not appear on the enclosed invitation, he
has really been the dynamo behind the Cuban affair. He sent me a dozen extra in-
vitations to send to the relatives of yellow fever personalities but I am sending
you one quite unofficially so that you may see who are involved. I am writing to
Doctor Nogueira at once telling him that I assume that an invitation has already
been sent to the American Embassy, telling him about certain American representa-
tives who wish to place wreaths in front of the medallions at the appropriate time
during the ceremony, etc. (His address is Marti 219, Marianao, Havana). He may
well telephone you or your secretary shotly.

As for the reception and the optimal time for it, I could of course say little as
I don't know exactly what they plan except I believe there is a meeting at the
Academy of Medicine the night of December 3. It would be indeed most pleasant if
a selected group of Americans and Cubans could meet at your home but I would not want
you to make it a troublesome affair for you. Americans suggested for invitations
would be of course General Streit, Commanding General of Walter Reed Hospital, who
will be the representative of the Surgeon General; Dr. L. M. Tocantins of Jeffer-
son Medical College, Philadelphia, from which Dr. Carlos Finlay graduated. He is
flying down for the ceremony. I will represent the Mayo Foundation. The following
representatives of the stated medical schools will be laying wreaths: For Harvard
Medical School in honor of General Wood, Mr. William W. Caswell, Jr., First National
Bank of Boston, Havana, Cuba; University of Maryland in honor of Doctor Carroll,
Dr. Jose R. Echeverria, Castillo Del Principe, Havana; Bellevue Medical School,
(New York University), in honor of Reed, Dr. Emilio Jayne of Havana; for the College
of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, to honor Agramonte, Lazear and
Sternberg, Dr. Raimundo de Castro, President of Columbia Alumni Club of Cuba and
Professor of Legal Medicine, University of Havana.

What Cubans should be invited, I leave up to you but I should think Doctor Saladrigas,
Minister of Health, Doctor Recio, Doctor Nogueira, Dr. Rodriguez Exposito, and of
Mr. Willard L. Beaulac

course President Batista. Also in the past Cuban Administration, the following
were very helpful with this project: Dr. Jose Andreu, the former Minister of
Health; Dr. Domingo Ramos, former Minister of Defense. Dr. Felipe Carbonell
has been very helpful to me and very interested in this project. I think some of
these gentlemen don't belong to the same political party. Through the years I
have worked with a number of conflicting elements. You will know better than I
what to do about this or, I should think, Dr. Nogueira could give you a very
fair summary of the situation. If I personally can be of any help, I should
be delighted and I will be available at the Hotel Nacional this Sunday morning.
I am indeed grateful for the interest you have shown in this matter.

I enclose a copy of the preliminary draft of my own remarks. They will be
shortened materially but it will give you further information about the inter-
relationships of the Finca San Jose, Doctor Finlay, Camp Lazear, etc.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
